name: Skepta
description:
'''Joseph Olaitan Adenuga Jr.''' (born 19 September 1982), known professionally as '''Skepta''', is a British [[Grime (music genre)|grime]] MC, rapper, record producer and DJ. Alongside his younger brother [[Jme (musician)|Jme]], he briefly joined [[Roll Deep]] before they became founding members of [[Boy Better Know]] in 2005.
With Boy Better Know, Skepta [[Sound clash|clashed]] with fellow MC Devilman for the video release ''[[Lord of the Mics]] 2'', in what is remembered as one of the biggest clashes in grime history.

Skepta released his debut studio album ''[[Greatest Hits (Skepta album)|Greatest Hits]]'' in 2007 and his second album, ''[[Microphone Champion]]'' in 2009, both independently; while his third studio album ''[[Doin' It Again]]'' was released in 2011 by [[All Around the World Productions|AATW]]. He made his acting debut in the 2015 film ''[[Anti-Social (2015 film)|Anti-Social]]''. Skepta's fourth studio album, ''[[Konnichiwa (Skepta album)|Konnichiwa]]'' (2016), featured the hit singles "[[That's Not Me (Skepta song)|That's Not Me]]" and "[[Shutdown (Skepta song)|Shutdown]]". The album, which was widely acclaimed, won the [[Mercury Prize]].

In 2018, he produced and was featured on American rapper [[ASAP Rocky]]'s single "[[Praise the Lord (Da Shine)]]", which became both artists' highest-charting single and a global hit. In 2019, Skepta released ''[[Ignorance Is Bliss (Skepta album)|Ignorance Is Bliss]]'', which charted in fifteen countries. ''[[Insomnia (Skepta, Chip and Young Adz album)|Insomnia]]'' (2020), a collaborative album with British rappers [[Chip (rapper)|Chip]] and [[Young Adz]], became Skepta's third album to reach the top 10 of the [[UK Albums Chart]].

Skepta has been nominated for three [[Brit Awards]], including the [[Brit Award for British Male Solo Artist]]. His influence on contemporary [[British popular culture]] as a key figure in the grime scene saw him appear on [[Debrett's]] 2017 list of the most influential people in the UK. He received a [[Nigerian chieftaincy]] on 4 April 2018, with his title being "Amuludun of Odo-Aje".
